segments.text: This is Tuesday, August 18, 1987.
I'm Bob Cornish, and I'm in the office of Kent Butler.
Kent is currently on leave from the University of Texas Department of Urban Planning.
community and regional planning, that is, with the Lower Colorado River Authority.
And Kent, let's take a look first of all at what you were doing when you were on the UT planning faculty.
I'd like to ask you first what you did to be eligible to join the faculty.
What was your background academically, and where did you do this sort of thing, and where did you, where were you located before coming to UT and so forth?
Okay, well, my first college training was at Penn, University of Pennsylvania, and I got turned on to planning and...
When were you there?
In the late 60s and early 70s, actually just two years, 69 through 71.
I see.
That was about three or four years after I was there.
Oh, okay.
Well, I was there at the vertex of the environmental movement.
Earth Day, original Earth Day, 1970, was right in the middle of my first college experience.
Well, that must have made quite an impression on you as a student, then, in planning.

Well, I started out in the Wharton School of Finance, and I quickly got dismayed by the gray flannel suits and the piqued interest of all of my student colleagues in marketing theory and things that had no sense of social importance to me.
At the same time, the city was alive with environmental concerns.
And the most outspoken person that I could get to was Ian McCarg.
And his program was in its heyday of teaching the whole concept of design with nature as people talk about it today.
So I took a course from McCarg and started
the first undergraduate degree program in landscape architecture and regional planning at Penn.
A combined degree?
Yes, it was an individualized major at the undergraduate level, and there were no undergraduate degrees there.
But I quickly got frustrated by the fact that that was an exceptional graduate school with little to offer in terms of undergraduate coursework.
So as much as I was turned on to the
program there I had to leave in order to get proper scientific training if I was to follow my instincts and become an environmental planner.
So I transferred to the Institute for Environmental Studies at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.
And there I stayed for seven years.
I got a bachelor's degree in environmental science, a master's degree in
water resources management, and a PhD in land resources.
All those degrees were multidisciplinary, interdepartmental in nature.
And I was able to develop a scientifically based degree in resources management and planning.
I should think so.
Pretty strong academic background for
The work you're doing right now, for example.
Yeah.
I was training myself to be working in the area of water resources, coastal land management.
I know you've had a lot of interest in that, California days and so on.
But no, I don't have the background, academic background in it that you have.
And my advisor was
took a leave of absence while I was working on my PhD and became the state planner, the director of planning and energy for Wisconsin.
Being a progressive state to begin with, I was able to get employment for two of the years I was in school with the state planning and energy office.
I worked on the Wisconsin coastal program.
So I had some kind of experience in Madison.
In Madison, yes.
Convenient.
Yeah.

So I had just a dabbling of the practical public sector planning experience as well as my academic work, and I was also able to work on some large-scale research projects, complete some research, and actually as a sort of a post-doctoral experience, I directed a research project on the use of science and technology information in the governor's office, scientific and technological research.
advisory roles of the various cabinet agencies advising the governor in Wisconsin, how it works from a decision-making process point of view.
So at the end of that experience, I decided to go back to academia so that I could continue research and begin teaching.
But I had little teaching experience before that.
But you knew you wanted to teach.
Yes, teach and do research in a very applied sense.
And I sought positions.
I had two or three offers.
But having grown up in Houston, having all my family and my wife's family in Houston, and always having a fond regard for Austin,
A job that opened up there that had tremendous flexibility and growth potential was a certain combination that I thought was the right thing for me at the time.
So there I went in 78 and stayed through 86 and now I'm at LCRA.
Okay.
When you were at UT,
What courses were you responsible for?

Well I ran, I headed up the environmental planning curriculum and in that area I taught courses in techniques of environmental analysis, which you might say are the physical planning techniques as well as
environmental analysis techniques.
I taught seminars, research seminars in environmental policy, environmental legislation.
I taught specialized courses such as coastal zone management and water resources management.
And then I also taught planning methods, which was a combination of physical planning and the various
social science analysis techniques that planners use in terms of making population projections and economic based analysis and the like.
I think Sandy does that sometimes, doesn't she?
Yeah.
In fact, in the last couple of years that I was teaching that course, Sandy and I would co-teach the course.

We'd actually split the program into smaller classes so that we would teach two classes at a time so that we'd have a more close working relationship with the students to make it more of a hands-on experience.
I did a lot of research.
I think from the second semester I was there until the last semester, over seven years, I had funded research consistently throughout that period.
And I felt lucky to be as successful as I was to have ongoing contract monies that allowed me to work in the summer, to engage a lot of students, to keep my
my time focused on some current topical issues.
Most of the research was in the area of either coastal zone management or water resources management.
But in the last couple of years I was there, I was more involved in urban growth management.
I spent a lot of time.
Well, you wrote an article for Hunting Magazine on growth management in Austin, as I recall.
Yeah, in ADA General.
In the journal?
Yeah.

That article had to do with negotiated growth management, which is getting into the area of negotiation and mediation, development agreements, an area which I had some opportunities to do some practical work as well.
I just saw, before I got here, you opened Dick Lilly, as I was getting out of my car, and we stopped and chatted.
Just coincidentally?
Of course, he's looking for things to do now that Barnes Connolly had gone bankrupt.
Did he tell you that he used to teach a comprehensive planning course once a year?
I knew that.
Three or four years.
And when I thought about it, I remembered what I asked him when he was a guest speaker at my class in comprehensive planning at A&M.
I asked him when Austin was going to come up with a comprehensive plan.
And he looked at me very seriously and said, I'm not sure we could ever do one.
And I subsequently had reason to believe him after seeing the Austin Tomorrow Plan.
You know, it's funny how things work.
His course always came down in the last six weeks on a studio project which addressed
prototypical, comprehensively planned, very large-scale development in southwest Austin.
And when he left the city, he went to work for Barnes Connolly to essentially manage the development of the Uplands Project, which was a four and a half thousand acre project in southwest Austin.
Interesting.
Looking back from your perspective now here at the River Authority toward the UT Planning Program, how would you characterize it?
Well, the program has a very energetic faculty and has been able to maintain a very
a stable size and high quality student body.
It's always been a program that reached out to the other departments on the campus, trying whenever possible to complement its teaching capabilities with other
departmental capabilities and giving a lot of flexibility to students to tailor programs to their desires and building upon their prior experiences.
The thrust of the program, I think, has been primarily in the area of policy planning with a strong quantitative methods requirement.
I compare it to the A&M planning program, which relative to the main thrust of the UT planning program is perhaps known more so for its physical planning capabilities.
But that's not to say that one is solely strong in one and the other in the other.
I think that's one distinction that I've often heard made, and I think there's some truth to it.
But the program has always been, I guess you'd say, lean and mean compared to the other larger planning programs throughout the country, which have higher faculty to student ratios, more faculty.
I think the faculty have always distinguished themselves from the architecture school within which it resides by having a very active and important research program.
I think that, as is always the case, there's two or three faculty that really
make that happen.
Sandy is certainly the leader in terms of bringing in some significant research.
Pat Wilson has been very active in research, and I was too.
I think we probably represented, and then when Del Myers was there, he did too.
But counting those of us that I just mentioned, we probably represented 90% of the
the active, funded research.
But that was always considered an important part of the academic program.
Either by employment or by informal means, such as running a research seminar, we brought that research into the classroom.
And again, a lot of that was policy planning, applied policy analysis.
as opposed to physical planning.
I did my share and Peter Coleman did some share of physical planning practicums, workshops, under contract with local governments in the state.
We did, I guess, in the seven years I was there, we probably did six or seven of those types of physical planning projects.
And they were generally quite successful, but I don't think those were our strengths.
I think those were essential complements in an overall planning program.

what um one more thing i think the program has always at least up until the last year or two maintained a very special and essential relationship with the city of austin through a combination of informal linkages and formal linkages to allow the students to take advantage of the
wonderful laboratory that Austin represents.

At one time, when I was running the intern program, we had as many as 17 interns working at the City of Austin at one time, and other interns were working in other places, but that just is an example of the level of commitment back and forth that was made to make Austin
the planning lab for the program, and for the program to be a research arm of the city of Austin.
Has that changed recently?
Well, it's changed quite a bit because of the economy in the 1986 and 87.
The employment capabilities of the city have gotten negative, as have very many cities, so that program is still working, but in large part it's
interns on a voluntary basis, or a nominal remuneration basis.
Whereas it used to be that the interns were paid more than the graduate research assistants.
And so we inadvertently did so well that we lost some of our better students in terms of their research potential to the intern program.
But the city also, through the informal context,

primarily through Terry Kahn and myself, and Dal Myers when he was there, used the university planning program as a research arm extensively, serving on boards and commissions, advising city council members on long-term planning issues,
Just maintaining that informal, peer-level dialogue with the planning professionals and the sovereign body of the city was something we always were very proud of and spent a lot of time doing.
Kent, we're now going to switch subjects, and this will not be under planning education for the transcriber.
This will be under various cities that you've been working with in the recent past.
Okay, let me get into this through sort of an autobiographical storytelling.
Having a background in water resources, I was taken with a monograph or a book that was written about ten years ago by three guys from Harvard, and the book is
was fairly popular at the time, and it's called Land Use and the Pipe.
And a sewer by any other name, you may say.
And essentially the thrust of that book and the thrust of the story it was telling along the lines of
the role of infrastructure in urban planning, is that notwithstanding roads, sewer and water lines are the veins and arteries of urban growth and suburban development.
And to that extent, I took a particular interest in the planning dimensions of infrastructure, particularly water and wastewater systems.
and I had just enough training to be able to really be conversant with the civil engineering profession and enough background in
finance to understand a little of the financial dimensions of financing infrastructure.
And through voluntary work in the city of Austin, I helped organize the city's Water and Wastewater Commission, which is an advisory body with some sovereign powers on which I served for four years.
And that commission reviewed virtually every water and wastewater approach line that was connected to the city.
And more importantly, along the lines of the practical planning work that I've done as a consultant, I reviewed and was involved in the decision making on the creation of muds.
municipal utility districts in the Austin jurisdiction.
In fact, while serving on that commission, I reviewed and was very heavily involved in the decisions to approve or deny some 23 muds in the Austin area.
And I was involved to the extent that council members would ask me to join them in the final early morning negotiation meetings with the mud developers and engineers and attorneys

on the day of the council meeting when the consent agreement would be finally moved and adopted, which would then authorize the mud to be created and the city to engage in joint participation in some of the infrastructure.
And to give you the scale of the significance of this, one project that I was involved in included $67 million worth of water and wastewater improvements.
One particular mud.
All told, there were over $800 million worth of water and wastewater improvements approved by the city that would be tied into the city utility as part of the build-out of these mud developments.
And I learned a lot about the legal and institutional and financial dimensions of municipal utility districts and their role vis-a-vis cities.
This was about the time that the Austin Tomorrow Plan was being formulated, wasn't it?
Well, it really came out on the coattails of that.
I became involved in this in 1980, and the Austin Tomorrow Plan was approved in 1980, finally approved in 1980.
And these muds were in response to a lot of the decisions by the city not to extend utility lines, not to allow the pipe to
determine where the city would grow.
And as a result, the city began to grow by a process of negotiated growth management.
And that's the story I try to tell in that article in the APA journal.
As a result of that experience, I
was asked to help other cities in the same regard.
The runaway story of muds in Houston was being played out again in Austin.
And it was beginning to happen in other cities as well.
The first city that I was asked to help in a position of negotiating the decision to approve or deny and if to approve under what terms to approve MUDS was in Missouri City.
And Missouri City is an interesting city because it is in many ways the epitome of Houston.
And I mention that because of your research on Houston.
Missouri City, not only because of the parkland dedication decisions is famous, is also famous because of the role of municipal utility districts.
The city has no water utility.
The city has no wastewater utility.
But it has some 35,000 people.
It has 19 LUDs within the city limits of Missouri City.
As a result, they
They have an extremely inefficient and expensive infrastructure.
The planning director called me one day and asked me to... Who was that?
Wayne... Snyder.
No.
Newman.
Newman.
Yeah, he's a former student of mine.
Yeah.
Yeah, he was.
And he... Well, the city had just received the final report of a comprehensive engineering analysis
of how could the city begin to consolidate all of these independent utilities.
And the report suggested that they begin to dissolve the muds within the middle of the city and to take over the debt and begin to put them together into a centralized utility system.
Who made that report, do you know?
Yeah.
Outside consulting firm?
Outside engineering consulting firm.
All right.
very well-known firm in Houston.
It was Pate Engineers, Jerry Pate and Associates.
I see.
At any rate, they asked me to look at it because of my knowledge about muds and the decision-making that go into mud approvals and the like.
And I looked at the report and I came to an interesting conclusion.
And I told them that I really felt that they needed to understand my conclusion in some detail because it didn't make sense to them at first.
My suggestion was that they not dissolve any muds within the city, but rather begin negotiating with any new muds on the fringe of the city to begin to tie them into a regional system.
And the thrust there is that planning activity generally occurs

where growth is occurring at the fringe, and the degree to which investment capital can be marshalled and directed to be of benefit to the public at large as well as the entrepreneur, then the spirit of a public-private partnership can be had.
And literally within a week of my making a series of recommendations along those lines,
Along came four new mud applications in the city.

And to make a long story short, I was hired by the city to review and negotiate the approval of those four new muds to create a city utility which would allow those muds to be created but which would require the water and wastewater improvements to be constructed by those muds to be dedicated to the city.
for ownership and operation with appropriate financial transactions to make it beneficial for the mud developers.
And so I began working with the city over a period of just three months to develop consent agreements

the four new muds representing a tremendous amount of development on the fringe of the city that were strategically located to put in a regional wastewater plant that would, over the course of years, be able to take over the operation of all the other muds inside the heart of the city.
And I think that is an example of

regional utilities infrastructure planning that makes sense economically that an engineer may not normally come to the same conclusion and that deals directly with what houston is having to face and i literally just coincidentally happen to have a article written by some members of houston mud boards
on their concept of regionalization, which is exactly what we're talking about.
Here's a series of seven muds on this figure I'm showing you that all decided to tie together.
And another example of three or four muds that decided to put in a regional plant and take advantage of the economy of scale.
Nothing unusual for planters to think that way and look at a larger area-wide issue,

What is surprising to me now in the Puget Sound area is that it's the public that is demanding economies and government, and they are insisting in regionalization and the dissolution of local units of government.
It's front page stuff in the Seattle paper.
Large feature articles on it frequently now.
It's continuing pressure.

Well, the unique character of this particular planning experience, I think, was the combination of the infrastructure planning and the multi-jurisdictional element, coupled with the need to develop, to utilize negotiation skills.
Someone who understood and had the respect of both sides, the city and the engineers and the developers and the financial advisors.
and who could see the benefits for both sides of a negotiated solution.

Later, I was hired by the city of San Marcos, which is in the Austin metropolitan district area, to do the same thing, to review two mud applications and to serve as negotiator for the city to allow those muds to be created
but to create an expanded city-owned and operated utility.

And after an arduous task of six months in length, four months were in fact created with the approval of the city to create a new regional wastewater and water system on the northern side of San Marcos back towards Austin.
It was a $42 million package of agreements
which, although it's not a lot of money by the scale of a metropolitan community, was a vast sum of money for a town of 35,000 people.
And along the same lines, I was almost immediately after that asked to help the city of McKinney, which is in the Dallas metro area.
Actually in, I forget the county.
It's not Dallas County, it's the next county up.

Anyway, the city of McKinney was not just approached, but woke up one morning reading in the newspapers that while each Ross Perot had proclaimed victory in advance of having purchased the Flying M Ranch, six and a half thousand acre ranch just
north of Dallas, just on the outskirts of McKinney, right in the area of Sherman and the future Saturn plant.
While H. Ruff slept that night, Gibraltar Savings at 11 p.m. consummated a purchase of the Flying M Ranch for something like $175 million cash.
and had assembled a team of planners and attorneys and landscape architects representing some 30 professionals to carry this project to completion and to work with
